tit.j: 往馬坐伊古麻都比古神社
tit.e: Ikomanimasuikomatsuhiko-jinja Shrine (a shrine in Ikoma City)
tit.cmt: "(a shrine in Ikoma City)" not necessary in a title.

sen.j: 往馬坐伊古麻都比古神社（いこまにますいこまつひこじんじゃ）は、奈良県生駒市にある神社である。
sen.e: Ikomanimasuikomatsuhiko-jinja Shrine is a shrine located in Ikoma City, Nara Prefecture.
Ikomanimasuikomatsuhiko-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Ikoma City, Nara Prefecture.
Ikomanimasuikomatsuhiko-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Ikoma City, Nara Prefecture.

sen.j: 式内社で、旧社格は県社。
sen.e: It is a Shikinai-sha (shrine listed in Engishiki laws) and a prefectural shrine (of prefectures other than Kyoto and Osaka) according to the old classification of shrines.
It is a Shikinai-sha (shrine listed in the Engishiki laws) and was classified as a prefectural shrine (of prefectures other than Kyoto and Osaka) under the old shrine classification system.
It is a Shikinai-sha (shrine listed in the Engishiki laws) and was classified as a prefectural shrine (of prefectures other than Kyoto and Osaka) under the old shrine classification system.

sen.j: 往馬大社（いこまたいしゃ）とも称し、生駒神社（いこまじんじゃ）と通称される。
sen.e: It is also referred to as Ikoma-taisha Shrine, and its common name is Ikoma-jinja Shrine.
It is also referred to as Ikoma-taisha Shrine, and its common name is Ikoma-jinja Shrine.
It is also referred to as Ikoma-taisha Shrine, and its common name is Ikoma-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 祭神
sen.e: Enshrined deities
Enshrined Deities
Enshrined deities
sen.cmt: 文頭のみ大文字にしました。

sen.j: 生駒山の神である伊古麻都比古神・伊古麻都比賣神、および氣長足比賣命（神功皇后）・足仲津比古命（仲哀天皇）・譽田別命（応神天皇）・ 葛城高額姫命（神功皇后の母）・息長宿禰王（神功皇后の父）を祀る。
sen.e: The enshrined deities are Ikomatsuhikonokami, Ikomatsuhimenokami (the gods of Mt. Ikoma), Okinagatarashihime no Mikoto (the Empress Jingu), Tarashinakatsuhiko no Mikoto (the Emperor Chuai), Homutawake no Mikoto (the Emperor Ojin), Katsuraginotakanukahime no Mikoto (the mother of the Empress Jingu) and Okinaga no sukune no Miko (the father of the Empress Jingu).
sen.cmt: 氣長足比賣命: 用語集には「Kinagatarashihime no Mikoto」と登録されていますが、「おきながたらしひめのみこと」(http://kotobank.jp/word/%E6%81%AF%E9%95%B7%E8%B6%B3%E5%AA%9B%E5%91%BD)ですので、本文ではこの読み方で記載しています。/譽田別命: 「Hondawake no Mikoto」と登録されていますが、「ほむたわけのみこと」(http://kotobank.jp/word/%E5%BF%9C%E7%A5%9E%E5%A4%A9%E7%9A%87)ですので、この読み方で記載しています。
sen.e: The enshrined deities are Ikomatsuhikonokami, Ikomatsuhimenokami (the gods of Mt. Ikoma), Okinagatarashihime no Mikoto (the Empress Jingu), Tarashinakatsuhiko no Mikoto (the Emperor Chuai), Homutawake no Mikoto (the Emperor Ojin), Katsuraginotakanukahime no Mikoto (the mother of the Empress Jingu) and Okinaga no sukune no Miko (the father of the Empress Jingu).

The enshrined deities are Ikomatsuhikonokami, Ikomatsuhimenokami (the gods of Mt. Ikoma), Okinagatarashihime no Mikoto (the Empress Jingu), Tarashinakatsuhiko no Mikoto (the Emperor Chuai), Homutawake no Mikoto (the Emperor Ojin), Katsuraginotakanukahime no Mikoto (the mother of the Empress Jingu) and Okinaga no sukune no Miko (the father of the Empress Jingu).

sen.j: 伊古麻都比古神・伊古麻都比賣神は古代より火を司る神として信仰されている。
sen.e: Ikomatsuhikonokami and Ikomatsuhimenokami have been worshiped as the gods that preside over fire since ancient times.
Ikomatsuhikonokami and Ikomatsuhimenokami have been worshiped as the gods that preside over fire since ancient times.
Ikomatsuhikonokami and Ikomatsuhimenokami have been worshiped as the gods that preside over fire since ancient times.

sen.j: 大嘗祭で用いられる浄火を起こす道具である火燧木は代々当社が献上することとなっている。
sen.e: This shrine has presented Hikirigi (the wood piece for ignition) used as the tool to ignite a sacred fire in the Daijo-sai festival (a festival to celebrate the succession of an emperor) for generations.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処/浄火: http://tangorin.com/words/浄火
sen.e: This shrine has presented Hikirigi (the wood piece for ignition) used as the tool to ignite a sacred fire in the Daijo-sai festival (a festival to celebrate the succession of an emperor) for generations.

This shrine has presented Hikirigi (the wood piece for ignition) used as the tool to ignite a sacred fire in the Daijo-sai festival (a festival to celebrate the succession of an emperor) for generations.

sen.j: 今上天皇の大嘗祭においても当社の火燧木が使用された。
sen.e: A Hikirigi presented by this shrine was used in the Daijo-sai festival of the present Emperor, too.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: A Hikirigi presented by this shrine was also used in the Daijo-sai festival of the present Emperor.
A Hikirigi presented by this shrine was also used in the Daijo-sai festival of the present Emperor.

sen.j: 『北山抄』『元要記』『亀相記』などには当社の神が「火燧木神（ひきりぎのかみ）」と書かれている。
sen.e: Books such as "Hokuzansho"(a representative book of ceremonies for the Heian period written by FUJIWARA no Kinto), "Genyoki" (a history book that is believed to have been written in the Kamakura period) and "Kisoki"(an abbreviation of "Shinsen kisoki," the oldest book about kiboku [tortoise-shell divination]) describe the gods of this shrine as 'the gods of Hikirigi.'
sen.cmt: 元要記: 読み方・定訳不明。「げんようき」と推測し、「鎌倉時代に書かれたと考えられる史書」(http://www.city.nara.nara.jp/www/contents/1147778065760/files/ado_repo-syu.pdf)という内容の説明を補足しています。/亀相記: 定訳不明。「新撰亀相記」(しんせんきそうき) (http://ci.nii.ac.jp/naid/110000247355)を指すと考えられるため、その意味の説明や、「http://k-amc.kokugakuin.ac.jp/DM/detail.do?class_name=col_dsg&data_id=68343」に基づく説明を補足しています(亀卜: http://tangorin.com/words/亀卜)/火燧木神: 定訳不明
sen.e: Books such as "Hokuzansho"(a representative book of ceremonies for the Heian period written by FUJIWARA no Kinto), "Genyoki" (a history book that is believed to have been written in the Kamakura period) and "Kisoki"(an abbreviation of "Shinsen kisoki," the oldest book about kiboku [tortoise-shell divination]) describe the gods of this shrine as 'the gods of Hikirigi.'

Books such as "Hokuzansho" (a representative book of ceremonies for the Heian period written by FUJIWARA no Kinto), "Genyoki" (a history book that is believed to have been written in the Kamakura period) and "Kisoki" (an abbreviation of "Shinsen kisoki," the oldest book about kiboku (tortoise-shell divination)) describe the gods of this shrine as 'the gods of Hikirigi.'
sen.cmt: スペース挿入しました。記号を修正しました。

sen.j: 10月第2日曜日（元は10月10日）の例祭は「火神祭」と呼ばれる。
sen.e: The reisai (regular festival) of the shrine is referred to as 'Fire God Festival" that has been held on the second Sunday of October, but it was originally held on October 10.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処/火神祭: 定訳は不明ですが、「火神」を「風神」「水神」の訳語に合わせ、「Fire God」として訳出しています。
sen.e: The reisai (regular festival) of the shrine is referred to as 'Fire God Festival" that has been held on the second Sunday of October, but it was originally held on October 10.
The reisai (regular festival) of the shrine is referred to as 'Fire God Festival' that has been held on the second Sunday of October, but it was originally held on October 10.

sen.j: 龍田大社の風神祭、廣瀬大社の水神祭とともに古来より朝廷の崇敬を受けてきた。
sen.e: The Imperial Court has revered the Fire God Festival, the Wind God Festival of Tatsuta-taisha Shrine and the Water God Festival of Hirose-taisha Shrine since ancient times.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処/龍田大社: 用語集には複数の訳語が登録されていますが、指示書に沿った訳語を記載しています。/風神祭: 用語集に「風神祭り」として登録されている用語を記載しています。/水神祭: 用語集では「水神」に対して別の訳語が登録されていますが、本文では、他の祭の表記法に合わせて訳出しています。
sen.e: The Imperial Court has revered the Fire God Festival, the Wind God Festival of Tatsuta-taisha Shrine and the Water God Festival of Hirose-taisha Shrine since ancient times.
The Imperial Court has revered the Fire God Festival, the Wind God Festival of Tatsuta-taisha Shrine and the Water God Festival of Hirose-taisha Shrine since ancient times.

sen.j: 歴史
sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: 創建の年代は不詳である。
sen.e: The year of its founding is unknown.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The year of its founding is unknown.
The year of its founding is unknown.

sen.j: だが、古代、当地に住みついた人々が生駒山を神体山として祀ったのを起源とするものとみられる。
sen.e: But it is believed to have originated from the fact that Mt. Ikoma was worshiped as Shintaizan (a mountain where the spirit of deity is traditionally believed to dwell) by those who settled down there in ancient times.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, it is believed to have originated from the fact that Mt. Ikoma was worshiped as Shintaizan (a mountain where the spirit of deity is traditionally believed to dwell) by those who settled there in ancient times.

However, it is believed to have originated from the fact that Mt. Ikoma was worshiped as Shintaizan (a mountain where the spirit of deity is traditionally believed to dwell) by those who settled there in ancient times.

sen.j: 文献での最も古い記述は、『総国風土記』の雄略天皇3年（458年）条に「伊古麻都比古神社」とあるものである。
sen.e: The oldest record in the literature can be found in the paragraph of the year 459 of "Sokokufudoki" (an ancient record of Japan), in which it is referred to as 'Ikomatsuhiko-jinja Shrine.'
sen.cmt: 総国風土記: 用語集の訳語に説明がないため、「http://en.factolex.com/Ikoma_Jinja」の説明を補足していますが、これは定訳ではありません。/雄略天皇3年: 実際には459年ですので、訳文ではそのように表記しています。
sen.e: The oldest record in the literature can be found in the paragraph of the year 459 of "Sokokufudoki" (an ancient record of Japan), in which it is referred to as 'Ikomatsuhiko-jinja Shrine.'
The oldest record in the literature can be found in the paragraph of the year 458 of "Sokokufudoki" (an ancient record of Japan), in which it is referred to as 'Ikomatsuhiko-jinja Shrine.'

sen.j: 延喜式神名帳では大和国平群郡「往馬坐伊古麻都比古神社二座」と記載されている。
sen.e: "Two deities of Ikomanimasuikomatsuhiko-jinja Shrine" in Hegurino-kori in Yamato Province are entered on Jinmyocho (the list of deities) of Engishiki (codes and procedures on national rites and prayers).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処/延喜式神名帳: 用語集には複数の訳語が登録されていますが、用語統一リストに従ったローマ字表記のものを採用しています。
sen.e: "Two deities of Ikomanimasuikomatsuhiko-jinja Shrine" in Hegurino-kori in Yamato Province are entered on Jinmyocho (the list of deities) of Engishiki (codes and procedures on national rites and prayers).

Two deities of Ikomanimasuikomatsuhiko-jinja Shrine' in Hegurino-kori in Yamato Province are entered on Jinmyocho (the list of deities) of Engishiki (codes and procedures on national rites and prayers).

sen.j: 大社に列し、月次・新嘗の奉幣に預ると記されている。
sen.e: The Jinmyocho of Engishiki states that it was classified into taisha (grand shrine) and was given hohei (offering of a wand with hemp and paper streamers to a Shinto god) in a Tsukinami-sai festival (a 'monthly' festival held in the Imperial Court, but actually only on two months of the year) and a Niiname-sai festival (ceremonial offering by the Emperor of newly-harvested rice to the deities).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処/月次・新嘗: 「monthly Niiname」と登録されていますが、新嘗は年1回の祭なので(http://kotobank.jp/word/%E6%96%B0%E5%98%97%E7%A5%AD)、不適切です。「新嘗」には登録されている訳語を充てましたが、「月次」に補足説明がないため、「http://books.google.com/books?id=GzeODCVG26UC&pg=PA42&dq=%22tsukinami+no+matsuri%22&hl=ja&ei=Fag-TOi8FY_CvQOqno3sDg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22tsukinami%20no%20matsuri%22&f=false」の「月次祭」の説明を参考にした説明を加えています。尚、「月次」に関して「monthly…」を用いた訳語が複数登録されていますが、「月次祭」は6月・12月に行われる祭なので(http://kotobank.jp/word/%E6%9C%88%E6%AC%A1%E7%A5%AD)、この用語を指す場合は、カッコ内のような補足説明が必要と思われます。/奉幣: 奉幣の初出の説明は、文脈に合わせて変更しています。
sen.e: The Jinmyocho of Engishiki states that it was classified as a taisha (grand shrine) and was given hohei (offering of a wand with hemp and paper streamers to a Shinto god) in a Tsukinami-sai festival (a 'monthly' festival held in the Imperial Court, but actually only on two months of the year) and a Niiname-sai festival (ceremonial offering by the Emperor of newly-harvested rice to the deities).

The Jinmyocho of Engishiki states that it was classified as a taisha (grand shrine) and was given hohei (offering of a wand with hemp and paper streamers to a Shinto god) in a Tsukinami-sai festival (a 'monthly' festival held in the Imperial Court, but actually only on two months of the year) and a Niiname-sai festival (ceremonial offering by the Emperor of newly-harvested rice to the deities).

sen.j: 鎌倉時代に八幡神が盛んになると、当社に八幡神にかかわる5柱の神が合祀された。
sen.e: As people came to believe enthusiastically in Hachimanshin (God of War) in the Kamakura period, five gods related to Hachimanshin were enshrined together in this shrine.
As people came to believe enthusiastically in Hachimanshin (God of War) in the Kamakura period, five gods related to Hachimanshin were enshrined together in this shrine.
As people came to believe enthusiastically in Hachimanshin (God of War) in the Kamakura period, five gods related to Hachimanshin were enshrined together in this shrine.

sen.j: 社殿
sen.e: Main building of the shrine
Main Building
Main building
sen.cmt: 文頭のみ大文字にしました。

sen.j: 拝殿の背後に、7連の春日造桧皮葺の本殿が建つ。
sen.e: The honden (main shrine) consisting of seven portions is built in the kasuga-zukuri style (a style of shrine architecture employed in main sanctuaries, that has the same basic form as that at Kasuga Taisha Shrine) behind the haiden (a hall of worship), and it is roofed with the bark of hinoki, Japanese cypress.
sen.cmt: 桧皮葺: 用語集の訳語は文構造に合わないため、分構造に合わせて変更しています。
sen.e: The honden (main shrine) consisting of seven portions is built in the kasuga-zukuri style (a style of shrine architecture employed in main sanctuaries, that has the same basic form as that at Kasuga Taisha Shrine) behind the haiden (a hall of worship), and it is roofed with the bark of hinoki, Japanese cypress.

The honden (main shrine) consisting of seven portions is built in the kasuga-zukuri style (a style of shrine architecture employed in main sanctuaries, that has the same basic form as that at Kasuga Taisha Shrine) behind the haiden (a hall of worship), and it is roofed with the bark of hinoki, Japanese cypress.

sen.j: 中央に伊古麻都比古命、その右に伊古麻都比咩命が祀られている。
sen.e: Ikomatsuhiko (another name of Ikomatsuhikonokami) is enshrined in the middle, and Ikomatsuhime no Mikoto (another name of Ikomatsuhimenokami) is enshrined on its right side.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処/伊古麻都比古命: 「いこまつひこ」(http://www.d3.dion.ne.jp/~stan/txt0/n4ikm01.htm)と読むようです。/伊古麻都比咩命: 「比咩命」は「ひめのみこと」と読むため(参考: http://kotobank.jp/word/%E6%B5%85%E4%BA%95%E6%AF%94%E5%92%A9%E5%91%BD)、「いこまつひめのみこと」と表記しています。
sen.e: Ikomatsuhiko (another name of Ikomatsuhikonokami) is enshrined in the middle, and Ikomatsuhime no Mikoto (another name of Ikomatsuhimenokami) is enshrined on its right side.
Ikomatsuhiko (another name of Ikomatsuhikonokami) is enshrined in the middle, and Ikomatsuhime no Mikoto (another name of Ikomatsuhimenokami) is enshrined on its right side.

sen.j: 左から息長宿禰王命・気長足姫命・誉田別命・伊古麻都比古命・伊古麻都比咩命・足仲彦命・葛城高額姫命の順となる。
sen.e: Starting from the left, the enshrined deities are Okinaga sukune o no Mikoto (another name of Okinaga no sukune no Miko), Okinagatarashihime no Mikoto, Homutawake no Mikoto, Ikomatsuhiko, Ikomatsuhime no Mikoto, Tarashinakatsuhiko no Mikoto and Katsuraginotakanukahime no Mikoto.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処/息長宿禰王命: 「http://www.narahaku.go.jp/collection/d-653-0-1.html」の「気長宿禰王命（おきながすくねおうのみこと）」と同一人物であり、「息長宿禰王」を指すと思われるため、その意味で訳しています。/気長足姫命: 「氣長足比賣命」を指します(既出の参考URLをご参照下さい)。/足仲彦命: 読み方は「たらしなかつひこのみこと」(http://www.doihata.jp/kagata/zasyuu2.htm)で、「足仲津比古命」を指します。
sen.e: Starting from the left, the enshrined deities are Okinaga sukune o no Mikoto (another name of Okinaga no sukune no Miko), Okinagatarashihime no Mikoto, Homutawake no Mikoto, Ikomatsuhiko, Ikomatsuhime no Mikoto, Tarashinakatsuhiko no Mikoto and Katsuraginotakanukahime no Mikoto.

Starting from the left, the enshrined deities are Okinaga sukune o no Mikoto (another name of Okinaga no sukune no Miko), Okinagatarashihime no Mikoto, Homutawake no Mikoto, Ikomatsuhiko, Ikomatsuhime no Mikoto, Tarashinakatsuhiko no Mikoto and Katsuraginotakanukahime no Mikoto.
